McCall said: “Our planned approach of achieving number one or two positions at Europe’s leading airports, friendly and efficient customer service and a continuous focus on sustainable cost control, has put easyJet at a strategic advantage during a period when there have been bankruptcies and some airlines have struggled operationally.” Profits before tax fell from £494m to £408m. Despite paying a lower dollar price for fuel, the continued weakness of sterling brought additional costs of £101m, easyJet said. The airline will also be prompted by Brexit to change its rules to ensure easyJet is majority owned and controlled by EU nationals after 2019. About a third of shares are owned by the easyJet founder, Stelios Haji-Ioannou, who has dual UK-Cypriot nationality, and will be classed as EU-owned. But easyJet will ask at its 2018 AGM for new powers to force UK shareholders to sell up if necessary to allow it to continue operating in Europe. McCall said the move was “a technical, administrative thing” and the airline had “no concerns” about getting enough EU shareholders. Shares rose by more than 5% in early trading, on the back of the airline reporting high levels of forward bookings and better revenue so far in its 2017-18 financial year, which it said was “primarily as a result of some capacity leaving the market”.
-------

Section 1
In the heart of a sprawling city, a businessman by the name of Richard sat in his glass tower office, contemplating his latest venture. He was an avid fisherman and daredevil, always looking for challenges that pushed limits. Richard had recently been following the struggling EasyJet airline and wondered if it could be turned around. The news about the company's plummeting profits and operating challenges during the Brexit period sparked a fire in his entrepreneurial spirit. He dared to believe that the key to turning EasyJet around lay in innovative customer service and cost control measures, much like outsmarting a fish at the perfect fishing spot.

Section 2
Richard acquainted himself with EasyJet's society, distributing surveys and asking employees about their experiences. He listened to passengers' feedback and coddled them with a proposition to improve EasyJet's reputation. Setting aside the numerous challenges that lay ahead, he had a strong belief that the proper investment and strategic planning would lead to success. Inspired by the thought of breathing life into a struggling entity, Richard treated his team to a series of brainstorming sessions to identify ways of turning EasyJet's situation around – one step at a time.

Section 3
Richard's ambitious journey wasn't without its share of setbacks; the weakened pound and rising fuel prices could make further investment in the company unviable. Knowing the hurdles they faced, Richard's team courageously designed a strategy to position EasyJet in a competitive advantage. As the team continued to take the necessary steps toward bolstering the struggling airline, shareholders began to show interest. One day, the once endangered EasyJet began to flourish, buoyed by a strong team, dedicated management, and an unconquerable spirit. Richard made his way up during the company's 2018 AGM, delivering compelling ideas and insights, such as how to ensure a majority of EU shareholders to ensure the smooth operation of the airline post-Brexit. With time, EasyJet regained its footing, sharing stories of perseverance and growth, much like a carefully crafted fishing tale that will be shared in society for generations to come.

turns:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 There are three broad categories of microbiome, named by Atlas, a company that will analyse the bacterial environment in your gut: the Urban Citizen, the Village Peasant and the Indigene. Your type can change if you significantly alter your diet. Anyone with any sense wants to be an Indigene, since the Urban Citizen is associated with the “western diet” (code for: “some Cinnamon Grahams and a KFC, what of it?”) and the Village Peasant sounds a bit, you know, dumpy. However, the Indigene is most prevalent in isolated tribespeople from the Amazon and Africa, or failing that, vegetarians. I got my results back from the £125 test I did in August, a complicated business of trapping poo on a piece of paper. I did this because your gut environment is as vital to your overall health as your hormonal one, or your brain chemistry; its health is determined by bacterial balance, which in turn is affected by your diet. I’m a Village Peasant. It turns out, now that I am one, they’re the best. I have bacteria from the Dorea genus to reduce inflammation of the gut, making it less likely that I’ll get Crohn’s disease. I have eubacterium, built by bananas and barley which, since I hate bananas, I can only ascribe to my high consumption of Ovaltine.
-------

turns:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The campaign group that encouraged Paperchase to apologise for its marketing activities with the Daily Mail is pushing for John Lewis, the department store chain, to stop advertising with the newspaper as well as with the Sun and Daily Express. John Lewis has become a prime target for Stop Funding Hate on the back of the launch of its Christmas advert and as retailers increase their spending on advertising as the festive season approaches. Stop Funding Hate has produced a mock advert that depicts the star of last year’s John Lewis Christmas advert – Buster the dog – as unhappy because the retailer is buying adverts with the Mail, Sun, and Express. The video has been shared almost 10,000 times on Twitter and Facebook. Sainsbury’s, Marks & Spencer and Waitrose are also being targeted by Stop Funding Hate. The organisation was founded last year and says its aim is to take on “divisive hate campaigns” by the Mail, Sun and Express, and persuade advertisers to cease their financial input. Richard Wilson, the founder of Stop Funding Hate, said: “[John Lewis] are a company well known for their ethical values and one that people have a lot of respect for. Customers are saying there is a clash between what the brand stands for and these newspapers. It would be great if John Lewis made a move, but another company could make a move too.” However, John Lewis said it would continue advertising with the newspapers and not bow to the pressure. A spokesperson said: “Withdrawing advertising on the basis of editorial coverage would be inconsistent with our democratic principles, which include freedom of speech and remaining apolitical.” Paperchase announced on Monday that it would not run any marketing campaigns with the Daily Mail and said it was “truly sorry” for running a front-page promotion in Saturday’s edition of the newspaper.
-------

Classic tales often find a way to breathe into modern settings, and this was precisely what was starting at the John Lewis offices. Mia, a simple employee at the department store, was coming to terms with the recent announcement. As she retweeted the 'Stop Funding Hate' campaign's mock advertisement showing Buster the dog, the star of last year’s John Lewis Christmas advert, looking unhappy due to the newsprint inks, she was struck with a sudden complex emotion. This felt like a familiar act of disapproval on part of the society - a tale that had repeated itself time and again in different scenarios. But what was the right path forward?

A debate had started at John Lewis. They were accused by the 'Stop Funding Hate' movement of underlining the 'divisive hate campaigns' of the Daily Mail, Sun, and Express, despite their intent to remain apolitical and uphold the democratic principle of freedom of speech. The dilemma was brewing, an internal war between ethical correctness and business interest. Yet, Mia was feeling the pressure not just from outside but from inside too, her fellow workers left her questioning whether John Lewis was really the place she wanted to work for. Would she be comfortable knowing that her beliefs had clashing ways with that of the company's?

Mia eventually made her decision. Despite her love for John Lewis and what they stood for, she stepped forward, penning a heartfelt letter to the upper management, highlighting the necessity of aligning with the collective sentiments. She explained that such a move would not only enhance public perception but also enhance the company's own ethical values. She knew that in this digital age, as important as freedom of speech is, protecting the values of society is equally as vital. Her message was heeded, and John Lewis announced they would not be purchasing further adverts from the disputed papers. She'd proudly had a role in the turnaround.
<|end_of_solution|>
